prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
WIBTA, for leaving my fiance of 7 years.
My fiance and I have been together for 7 years now and have an almost 6 year old son together.

Almost 3 years ago now we had broken up for about a month. During this time he began to talk to a girl that he's known for most of his life. We got back together, and I expected him to break off all contact with her. Which I thought was understandable.

2 weeks in and he still has her on all social media including snapchat. We fought and fought over it and he eventually deleted her. Or so I thought.

Last October, we had been growing rather distant and I took it upon myself to snoop through his phone.

And there she is. She had blocked me on social media so that I couldn't see them following each other. He had literally liked every single one of her pictures, not any of mine during the same time period to be clear, and she liked his as well. Including a picture of his Snapchat code asking people to add him.

I confront him. He becomes angry and defensive but swears hell get rid of her.

About a month later I decide to check again. And she's still there. So I told him I was leaving him.

He left for about 3 days. And we eventually talked things through and he again swore to delete her and block her for good.

3 weeks ago, I saw that he had liked pictures of the girl's sister on Instagram. He says he had remembered liking them from a long time ago and had been trying to unlike them so I would never find them and in doing so accidentally re liked the pictures, and I believed him.

Last night. He has both the girl AND her sister unblocked AGAIN on social media. Meaning he went out of his way to go through his settings, get to privacy, open his list of blocked users and unblocked those two in particular.

WIBTA for ending a 7 year relationship with the father of my son because he can't seem to let go of some other girl? Even though the only thing I really have evidence of is them staying in contact, not actually cheating?

I'm at a complete loss.
"""

I think the author is in the wrong but curious what you think.
Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

thinking.text:
Okay, let's break this down. The user is asking whether the author of the original situation is in the wrong for leaving their fiancé after 7 years. The main issue is about the fiancé maintaining contact with another girl despite promises to cut off contact.

First, the fiancé had a history of keeping the girl on social media, even after arguments and promises to delete her. The author snoopied through the phone and found ongoing likes on the girl's pictures. The fiancé would promise to remove her each time but failed. Then, the sister was also liked, and finally, the fiancé unblocked both the girl and her sister. The author ends the relationship because of this, even without proof of cheating.

The user thinks the author might be wrong, but others might argue that maintaining contact with someone in a committed relationship is a red flag. The question is whether the author is justified in ending the relationship.

Factors to consider: The fiancé's repeated failures to honor his promises, the ongoing contact despite being asked to stop, and the author's concern for their relationship's integrity. The author has a child with the fiancé, so trust and stability are crucial. Even without cheating, emotional infidelity or betrayal of trust could be a valid reason to leave. The author's actions (snooping) might be questionable, but the reason for doing so was to uncover breaches of trust.

On the other hand, some might say the author is overreacting, but given the repeated issues and the fiancé's lack of commitment to fix the problem, the author's decision could be seen as justified. The key is whether the fiancé respected the boundaries set by the author. If not, the author isn't necessarily wrong to leave.
